data: Ephemeris epigraphica. Corporis inscriptionum Latinarum supplementum, edita iussu Instituti archaeologici Romani
W. Henzen and K. F. W. Zangemeister, Ephemeris Epigraphica. Corporis Inscriptionum Latinarum Supplementum, Edita Iussu Instituti Archaeologici Romani, 9 vols (Berlin: G. Reimerum, 1872)
Two lines of Latin letters with guide lines not always closely observed, the first line much larger than the second, filling the surviving face.
Tall v-cut letters, with slight upward angle to the horizontals, and serifs; open P.

Two lines of latin letters, seemingly centred on the stone and beginning from the top, with vacat below.
Tall v-cut letters, with serifs, horizontals slightly angled upwards; interpuncts vary in form.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2023-07-05.

Four lines of Latin letters, seemingly roughly aligned on the left, decreasing in size.
Deeply incised letters with pronounced serifs and comma-shaped interpuncts. Tall I in line 1, sloping cross-bars to alpha, G with curled foot, M with extended upper strokes.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J.Prag 06.07.2023

Four lines of Latin letters, probably centred on the stone, first line centred, lines 2-4 maintaining a consistent left margin.
V-cut letters with serifs and use of lightly incised small hederae; M slightly extended upper strokes, A with slping cross bar, E and L with downward sloping bars.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2022-07-13.

Funerary inscription for a Claud[---] Fort[---]
Three lines of fragmentary Latin text (a fourth line is possible, but the break obscures this; the epigraphic formula suggests three lines only). There is a large vacat on the left side of all text.

The text is irregularly and shakily carved. Letter height and width differ even on the same line, and the T on line 2 is significantly taller than other letters. Simple serifs used. The vertical bar for the 'R' in line 2 is bisected by a long horizontal foot. At the end of line 2, the top of a serifed downstroke is just visible after the T.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2023-07-04.
funerary inscription for a claud[---] fort[---]

1Claud[---]
2Fortụ[---]
3vix(it) [an(nis) ---]

Traces are visible of three lines of text, but it is possible, from the spacing, that a fourth line (which would be line 3 of the text) is simply completely lost; the spacing would be tight, however, and more plausibly there is simply a vacat between lines 2 and 3, after the name and prior to the record of age at death, a simple formulation that finds multiple parallels at Termini.
Simply cut, somewhat irregular letters of varying width, with extended upper strokes and pronounced serifs.
Manganaro, 1988, La Sicilia da Sesto Pompeo a Diocleziano

Three lines of Latin letters, seemingly maintaining a consistent left margin, but irregular right margin, with a large vacat after DMS in line 1.
Deep cut letters, with extended apices and somewhat irregular in layout and size. Deep serifs and occasional hederae but no interpuncts.
Ferrua dates to the 3rd century CE on the basis of the letter forms.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2023-07-04

Three lines of complete Latin text.
Letter height is somewhat uneven. Incomplete downward left sloping cross-bar on 'A's throughout. Prominent serifs, with top of A very extended. Lines of letters not always conjoined.
Ciofalo, 1876-, Notizie degli scavi di antichità

Funerary plaque for Lesbius and Damophilus
Three lines of Latin text, without much room on sides. Multiple types of interpunct used throughout, although all faint on stone.

Text is relatively regular and neat, although stonecarver was not able to achieve straight lines on all letters (for instance, the wobbly 'D' in line 2). Serifs used on all letters. The cross-bar on the As are barely noticeable.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2023-07-05

Fragment of a dedication to Venus Erycina

The text is arranged over nine lines. The first two lines (praescriptio), larger than the others, are placed across the top. Two columns follow (b and c), the first one consisting of two lines (and a vacat) and the second one of seven. Lines 1-2 of the left column form a separate text from lines 1-2 in the right column. The space between the columns is 2.4 cm.

Scriptura actuaria with letters made with the brush edge at an angle of less than 30 degrees to the writing line (rustica). All letters, except the last "a" in column 2, line 8, are rubricated, but most of the colour appears too bright to be ancient (and appears identical to that with which the inventory number on the lower left corner has been applied); it also appears that not all the interpuncts have been rubricated.
Photo C. Vacanti with the collaboration and permission of the Museo Regionale di Trapani Agostino Pepoli

l.1 reg., orig. SICIRIBONIUSSiciribonius
The text is engraved in a single line across the middle of the three vertical surfaces on the front face of the stone.

Tall, narrow and slightly uneven, v-cut letters with some use of serifs; diminishing in height towards line end. A has a cross-bar which extends beyond the uprights on both sides, sloping down to the left; E has strokes of approximately equal length; P and R are open; S has larger upper half.
The formula perpetuus Augustus is typical of the fourth century
Photo J. Prag (2018), Aut. Assessorato Beni Culturali Regione Siciliana n.10681 del 06/05/2014
1[---p]erpetuus Aug̣[ustus---]
Latin text, aligned to the left margin over two lines, with guidelines (no interlinear spacing)

Somewhat irregularly spaced tall letters, with thin strokes but pronounced terminations to the strokes.  A has a detached downward descending middle-bar; E is tall thin, with shorter top bar; G is formed as a C with the tail a second short curving stroke; P is closed; R has small eye, slightly open; S leans forward slightly. The use of interpuncts is erractic and seemingly not linked to sense, with a triangular punct after the initial A and at the end of line 2; a large reversed comma-shape midline after the R of line 1; and a smaller comma-shape mid-line between V and R in line 2.
Photo J. Prag, Aut. Assessorato Beni Culturali Regione Siciliana n.10681 del 06/05/2014

1A·per · (vac.6)
2Augu·rinus ·
Fragment of a Latin funerary inscription
Four lines of Latin letters, with an uneven left margin, and of varying heights, the final line much smaller and with space mid-line.

Neat v-cut letters of rather square/blockish style, with simple straight serifs to ends of the strokes. T in line 2 is enlarged (50mm) and as is final I in line 4. Interpuncts of triangular form. C is large and asymmetrical; E has equal length horizontals.
fragment of a latin funerary inscription

1Ḅụṛọ[---]
2T(itus) · Flav[---]
3Caelia [---]
4sibi · (vac.)[---]
Well-spaced lines filling the width of the available stone, word-breaks do not observe line-end.

Somewhat irregular deep-cut letters with pronounced terminations and occasionally extravagant serifs/flourishes (e.g. on X or E), and a varying tendency to the later narrow elongated style (e.g. TFL in line 5), and M sometimes with the upper strokes extended well above the join. A consistently lacks a cross-bar; E generally has equal length strokes, but with the top stroke often extended upwards; F, tall, narrow, and upward pointing; M sometimes with extended apices, sometimes without (all four strokes full length); P is closed; R sometimes open, with extended tail; X frequently over extended upper right. No interpuncts.
mid-2nd century to mid-4th century CE
Photo J. Prag (2015), Aut. Assessorato Beni Culturali Regione Siciliana n.10681 del 06/05/2014

Latin text over three lines. The two letters of the third line are centred and
                                        much smaller

Neat v-cut letters, well, but not perfectly spaced and regular, with deep triangular
                                    serifs, and deep triangular interpuncts between every word. Long 'I' is elongated.
Spigo, 2004, Archeologia a Capo d'Orlando: studi per l'Antiquarium

Pellegrini describes the form of the letters as similar to that  and ; he also notes that they have been painted in red, although he appears to imply that this was done in modern times, with the praecnomen and the interpunct of line 9 remaining unpainted.
Dated to the period of Diocletian or Constantine, but probably prior to 314 CE, on the basis of the office and titles
Di Stefano, 1984, Lilibeo. Testimonianze archeologiche dal IV sec a.C. al V sec. d.C.
